summary: This is an email chain from June 2008 between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing the status of a plea agreement with Jeffrey Epstein. It shows the government asserting a binding agreement exists and planning discussions about the plea and sentencing.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Addressed in an email from a U.S. Attorney regarding the Jeffrey Epstein agreement, indicating he is part of the defense legal team.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Addressed alongside Roy Black in an email from a U.S. Attorney regarding the Jeffrey Epstein agreement, indicating he is part of the defense legal team.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the plea agreement being discussed between the U.S. Attorney's Office and defense attorneys.

connections.description: Both are addressed together as recipients of an email from a U.S. Attorney regarding the Epstein plea agreement, indicating they are working together as defense attorneys.
Roy Black is addressed as part of the defense team in correspondence about Epstein's plea agreement.
Jack Goldberger is addressed as part of the defense team in correspondence about Epstein's plea agreement.

events.title: Government asserts binding Epstein agreement
events.description: A U.S. Attorney emails defense attorneys Roy Black and Jack Goldberger stating the government's position that a signed, binding plea agreement with Jeffrey Epstein exists and requires no further modification.

events.title: Planning discussions on Epstein plea
events.description: Email correspondence indicates plans to discuss the plea agreement and mentions finishing search warrants before a call.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office asserted on June 24, 2008, that a signed, binding plea agreement with Jeffrey Epstein existed and required no further modification.
Defense attorneys Roy Black and Jack Goldberger were the points of contact for the Epstein defense team regarding the plea agreement.
Internal government emails show coordination and planning for discussions about Epstein's change of plea and sentencing.
The correspondence references ongoing work on search warrants in relation to the Epstein case.
